content: H.R. 3962, Affordable Health Care for America Act, passed by the House of Representatives on November 7, 2009, is based on H.R. 3200. The Congressional Budget Office estimates it would reduce federal deficits by $109 billion over 10 years and insure 96% of the non-elderly population by 2019. The bill, H.R. 3962, would reduce federal deficits by $109 billion over 10 years and insure 96% of the non-elderly population by 2019. The net cost of the coverage provisions would be $891 billion over 10 years, offset by other spending changes and increased federal revenues. The Affordable Health Care for America Act, H.R. 3962, would save $427 billion through spending changes and increase federal revenues by $574 billion. The bill aims to reduce the number of uninsured, restructure the private health insurance market, set minimum health benefit standards, provide financial assistance, and require individuals to maintain health insurance. H.R. 3962 aims to reduce the number of uninsured by requiring individuals to maintain health insurance and employers to provide insurance or pay a payroll assessment. Market reforms like modified community rating and guaranteed issue would be implemented, with acceptable coverage including plans offered through the Exchange, employer plans, Medicare, and Medicaid. The Exchange, established under a new federal agency, would offer private plans alongside a public option. Subsidies for premium costs and cost-sharing would be available for individuals with incomes below 400% of the federal poverty level. Plans in the individual market could be grandfathered indefinitely if no changes were made. The bill also includes a Consumer Operated and Oriented Plan (CO-OP) program. The bill would establish a Consumer Operated and Oriented Plan (CO-OP) program to create not-for-profit health insurance cooperatives in the Exchange. It would not affect plans for specific services like dental or vision care. Revenues would be raised by limiting employer deductions for certain health insurance plans and modifying tax-advantaged accounts for health care spending.
